TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @misc{Wiki_pwn_nipaluma-kawayna, title = nipaluma-kawayna, year = 2024, month = November, day = 18, note = {In Wikipedia [Paiwan]}, url = {https://pwn.wikipedia.org/wiki/nipaluma-kawayna} }

S.FORM: kawayna ( : , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ) taneng miazih atu mukan. sikapahay a sangek i labii. u masay kilang a nipaluma'. malicangay a balu taneng micebus tu akuti'ay a nanum, taneng mukan. kagak kakuniza subal: Eukaryota salaedan: Plantae panan: Magnoliophyta upiz: Magnoliopsida mata: Dipsacales sapamat: Caprifoliaceae mikitinay: Lonicera hicahicaay: L. japonica u siwkay nu nipaluma u sanek nu nipaluma malaheci tu imelang pasubana i cacudadan a lacul u zuma a cidekay a kamu, saungay misapayu' a cidekay u sulit nu zuma a kamu Hulam atu Amilika ( :Lonicera japonica) , , , , , , . . 3 4 (0.12 0.16 ) . Lonicera japonica, known as golden and silver honeysuckle or Japanese honeysuckle in English, suikazura ( or ) in Japanese, jinyinhua or rendongteng in Chinese, indongdeonggul in Korean, and kim ng√¢n hoa in Vietnamese, is a species of honeysuckle native to eastern Asia including China, Japan and Korea. It is a twining vine able to climb up to 10 m (33 ft) high or more in trees, with opposite, simple oval leaves 3 8 cm (1.2 3.1 in) long and 2 3 cm (0.79 1.18 in) broad. The flowers are double tongued, opening white and fading to yellow, and sweetly vanilla scented. The fruit is a black spherical berry 3 4 mm (0.12 0.16 in) diameter containing a few seeds. namakayniay a nasulitan nasakamuan atu natinengan . .
